member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvConfigurationWriter
member.summary: Save the state of the system.
member.remarks:
You can save:
The GigE Vision device's state (all parameters that can be streamed).
The SDK's state (stream information and information needed to connect to a GigE Vision device).
Your own custom strings and property lists.
To save your state information:
1. Create a configuration writer. Use .
2. Store state information in the configuration writer.
For GigE Vision device controllers (PvDevice objects), use Store(PvDevice, String).
For GigE Vision stream channel receivers (PvStream objects), use Store(PvStream, String).
3. Optionally, store your own state information. Use Store(String, String).
4. Optionally, repeat the two previous steps.
5. Save the stored information to disk. Use . To load your state information: see

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvIPEngineI2CBus.BurstWrite(System.Byte,System.String,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Send a command to the camera.
member.remarks:
Before using BurstWrite, confirm it meets your camera's requirements:
If your I2C-capable camera uses a single memory location (for the entire streamed message, use BurstWrite and BurstRead.
If it uses sequential memory (storing messages in a series of bytes in memory), use IndirectBurstWrite and IndirectBurstRead.
The BurstWrite method sends a message, aBuffer, to the I2C-capable camera defined by aSlaveAddress.
If the camera doesn't acknowledge a byte during the burst write, BurstWrite terminates early, but returns PV_RESULT_OK.
member.param: The camera's I2C slave address (7-bits).
A handle to the data being sent to the camera.
The buffer's size.
The I2C bus speed. Default value is True for I2C's Fast mode (400 Kbits/s); false for Standard mode (100 Kbits/s).
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing the following result code:
if the port is not initialized.
if the port is not opened or the associated PvDevice is no longer connected.
if not all bytes could be written to the serial port.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvIPEngineI2CBus.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvIPEngineI2CBus
member.summary: I2C serial controller.

remarks.para: The PvIPEngineI2CBus lets you send commands to your camera and receive the camera's replies.

I2C uses the concept of a master and slave, where the master controls the clock and initiates reads and writes. For PvIPEngineI2CBus, the IP Engine is the I2C master. The I2C slave is typically a camera, but could be any I2C-capable device connected to the IP Engine.

The PvIPEngineI2CBus methods manage the entire IP Engine and camera communication required to send a message to the camera. For example, the BurstWrite method involves the following transaction:
PC calls BurstWrite.
PC passes entire message to the IP Engine via Ethernet.
BurstWrite blocks.
IP Engine to camera: [Start condition] aSlaveAddress [Write - SDA low].
Camera to IP Engine: Acknowledge.
IP Engine to camera: [First 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to IP Engine: Acknowledge.
IP Engine to camera: [Next 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to IP Engine: Acknowledge.
...
IP Engine to camera: [Last 8 bits of aBuffer].
Camera to IP Engine: Acknowledge.
IP Engine to camera: [Stop condition].
IP Engine reports the successful transmission of the message to the PC (via Ethernet).
BurstWrite method unblocks (returns).
For the complete hardware-level transactions for all PvIPEngineI2CBus methods, see your hardware guide.

para.b: To send I2C-protocol serial commands to your camera:

item.description: Create an I2C serial controller of the PvIPEngineI2CBus class.
Send a command to the camera. Use BurstWrite.
Test to ensure the message send succeeded. Check the PvResult returned by BurstWrite.
Retrieve the camera's reply. Use BurstRead.
Test to ensure the message retrieval succeeded. Check the PvResult returned by BurstRead.
Test the content of the message from the camera. Use aBuffer and aBufferSize parameters and your own code.

remarks.para: For a simple example illustrating how to use PvIPEngineI2CBus, refer to the sample entitled PvI2CSample.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.Resend(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Resends the action command using the same request ID.

remark.para: An application receiving an action command with the same request ID will acknowledge it but not execute the action if it was previously received.

Resends are not managed automatically as all application may have different requirements when it comes to resending actions. They need to be explicitly managed and performed if acknowledgements are missing.

member.param: Maximum time to wait for answers in ms.
If different than zero, Send can return as soon as aDeviceCount acknowledges have been received without having to wait for aTimeout.
Sets the request acknowledge bit of the action commmand, instructing the devices to acknowledge the command.
member.returns: If the provided timeout expired before the reception of all the acknowledges If the command was never sent before calling Resend If the content of the command has changed since the last Send operation. A resend cannot be performed if the command is not exactly the same.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.Send(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Broadcasts the action command on all enabled network interfaces.

remark.para: If more than one network interface is enabled, broadcasts are sent on each network interface (one after the other, in the order they were added to the action command object) and do not wait for any acknowledgements. When Send is used, the request ID of the action command is automatically incremented. Use to send the same action without incrementing the request ID.

The action command itself does not know how many devices are reached with this broadcast: all devices receiving the action command and configured to react to it (combination of device key, group key and group mask) are expected to perform the task associated with it.

member.param: Maximum time to wait for answers in ms.
If different than zero, Send can return as soon as aDeviceCount acknowledges have been received without having to wait for aTimeout.
Sets the request acknowledge bit of the action commmand, instructing the devices to acknowledge the command.
member.returns: If the provided timeout expired before the reception of all acknowledgements.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.Send(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Broadcasts the action command on all enabled network interfaces.

remark.para: If more than one network interface is enabled, broadcasts are sent on each network interface (one after the other, in the order they were added to the action command object) and waits for acknowledgements. When Send is used, the request ID of the action command is automatically incremented. Use to send the same action without incrementing the request ID.
When using this overload of the Send function, acknowledgements are asked from the device.

The action command itself does not know how many devices are reached with this broadcast: all devices receiving the action command and configured to react to it (combination of device key, group key and group mask) are expected to perform the task associated with it.

member.param: Maximum time to wait for answers in ms.
If different than zero, Send can return as soon as aDeviceCount acknowledges have been received without having to wait for aTimeout.
member.returns: If the provided timeout expired before the reception of all the acknowledgements.

When Send is used, the request ID of the action command is automatically incremented. Use to send the same action without incrementing the request ID.
When using this overload of the Send function, acknowledgements are asked from the device.

The action command itself does not know how many devices are reached with this broadcast: all devices receiving the action command and configured to react to it (combination of device key, group key and group mask) are expected to perform the task associated with it.

member.param: Time to wait for answers in ms.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.ScheduledTime
member.summary: Gets and sets the scheduled time for the action command.

remarks.para: Action commands can either be performed on reception (no scheduled time enabled or provided) or they can be scheduled in the future. If a timestamp (device time domain) is provided, the device queues the action command and performs the associated task as close to the scheduled action command timestamp as possible. If the device receives a timestamp set in the past relative to its time domain, it is expected to execute the command on reception. The queue the device uses to hold future actions may be limited. If a new command is received and the device is not able to add it to a full queue, the sender is notified (if an acknowledgement of the action command was requested).
The scheduled time is only used when the scheduled time is enabled.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.ScheduledTimeEnable
member.summary: Gets and sets current action command scheduled time enabling state.
member.remarks: Action commands can either be performed on reception (no scheduled time enabled or provided) or they can be scheduled in the future. This function allows the user to control when the scheduled action command is enabled.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.GroupMask
member.summary: Gets and sets current action command group mask.
member.remarks: A group mask can be configured for an action command. This mask is applied by the device against the group mask of the action command. If the resulting value is non-zero, the action is executed by the device. The group mask for device actions is typically configured using the GenICam(TM) interface of the device. The group mask is defined at the action level: different actions on a device can have different group masks.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.GroupKey
member.summary: Gets and sets current action command group key
member.remarks: The group key defines a group of devices on which actions have to be executed. If a device supports action 1 with a group key of 0x24 and action 2 with a group key of 0x42, when an action command with group key 0x24 is sent, only action 1 is executed. The group key for device actions is typically configured using the GenICam(TM) interface of a device. The group key is defined at the action level: different actions on a device can have a different group keys.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand.DeviceKey
member.summary: Gets and sets current action command device key.
member.remarks: The device key is a 32-bit value used to check the validity of action commands. Devices only process action commands if the action command's device key matches the device's device key – think of it as a secret password provided by action commands that must match the password configured on the device. The device key on the device is typically configured using the GenICam(TM) interface of the device. The device key is defined at the device level.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvActionCommand
member.summary: Utility class to send action commands.

remarks.para: PvActionCommand adds the ability to fire action commands, as defined in the GigE Vision(R) standard.

To use a PvActionCommand, you instantiate an object from the class, configure the command to send, send the command and then optionally retrieve statistics about the outcome of the command. It is possible to use the same action command object to send more than one command: to send the same command, call Send as many times as required. To send different commands, change the configuration of the command between Send calls.

The eBUS SDK does not configure action commands on the device directly. Instead, the SDK assumes that the user is manually configuring action commands with the GenICam(TM) browser in the GEVPlayer sample application, or is configuring action commands programmatically (assuming that the device’s GenICam interface allows the user to configure the device directly).

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvGenFile.Status
member.summary: Gets the status of the last operation on a PvGenFile.

remarks.para: Last status of a read or write operation as provided by the device. The only enum entry guaranteed to be provided by all devices is "Success" and everything else is quality of implementation.
As an example, the reference GenApi implementation for files assumes end-of-file (EOF) if anything else other than "Success" is reported after a read or a write.
Open, Close, Read and Write operations can get the status through GetStatus. The GetStatus shows the success or failure (or EOF) of the operation on the device.

member.exception:

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDisplayThread.OnBufferDisplay
member.summary: A buffer needs to be displayed.

remarks.para: If the acquisition frame rate is higher than the target FPS some buffers may end up not being displayed.
Additional processing may be performed before displaying the image. This step is optional and left to the application. The display thread does not perform image processing.

If interlacing is enabled and an interlaced stream is handled by the display thread, the final buffer being displayed is a buffer that is not directly retrieved from the pipeline (and reported through OnBufferRetrieved). It is a buffer owned by the display thread used for image reconstruction from received field buffers.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.OnBufferTooSmall
member.summary: PvPipeline event sink OnBufferTooSmall event.

remarks.para: Invoked when the pipeline retrieve a buffer from the stream object which failed with an operation result set to BUFFER_TOO_SMALL.
The user can set the delegate aReallocAll parameter to true in order to force a complete re-allocation of the buffers performed synchronously after the notification is invoked.

If OnBufferTooSmall is not handled or the delegate aReallocAll parameter is set to false, the buffer is re-allocated before being queued in the stream object but the other buffers are not affected until they too will fail on BUFFER_TOO_SMALL.
The delegate aResetStats parameter is only considered if the delegate aReallocAll is set to true. The statistics do not need to be reset if the buffers are not re-allocated.
This callback is invoked from the pipeline thread.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.BufferHandlingThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the pipeline thread.
member.remarks:
This thread is pretty much the pipeline itself: it queues buffers in PvStream and retrieves them when they are ready, making them available in an output queue.
If you change the thread priorities, it may alternate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvPipeline.HandleBufferTooSmall
member.summary: Configures whether the pipeline handles BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation result or not.

remarks.para: If the pipeline is configured to handle BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results the buffers are automatically re-allocated and re-queued for acquisition when this condition occurs.

If the pipeline is not configured to handled BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results the buffers are queued in the pipeline output queue just as any other buffer and what to do with the buffer is deferred to the application using PvPipeline.

If the pipeline handles BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results, the OnBufferTooSmall delegate is invoked in order to order to query how to handle the condition. If not implemented the default behaviour is applied. See documentation about the OnBufferTooSmall delegate for more information.
The OnBufferTooSmall delegate is not invoked when the pipeline is not configured to handle BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation results.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvPipeline
member.summary: Helper class for receiving data from a GigE Vision transmitter.

item.description: PvPipeline manages the PvBuffer and acquisition thread.
PvPipeline partners with a PvStream or PvStreamRaw object to allocate and push buffers into the data receiver as needed.
Only applied to simple acquisition scenarios.
Only responsible of receiving images.
Buffers are silently dropped when the out-queue of the PvPipeline is full.
Does not interact with IP engine.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.OnBufferTooSmall
member.summary: PvPipeline buffer too small event delegate.
member.param: Reference to the PvPipeline object that invoked the delegate.

Output parameter: if set to true by the delegate handler, all buffers of the pipeline will be re-allocated immediately. If set to false, buffers are re-allocated one-by-one as they fail with BUFFER_TOO_SMALL operation result.
Output parameter: if true, the statistics are reset following buffers re-allocation.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvAcquisitionStateManager
member.summary: Acquisition state manager, advanced TLParamsLocked manager.

remarks.para: Contains logic to manage the TLParamsLocked GenICam parameter of a PvDevice over various acquisition modes.

A PvDevice is provided to the constructor of this class. A PvStream is also usually provided. The Start and Stop methods are invoked to start and stop the acquisition. If a stream is not provided, the acquisition state has to be reset manually for some acquisition mode as incoming buffers cannot be reported/counted.

It takes control of issuing Start/Stop methods to the AcquisitionStart and AcquisitionStop GenICam commands of a device. It also counts frames (when applicable) to automatically release TLParamsLocked when all the buffers have been accounted for. It is possible to cancel the operation pre-emptively by calling Stop - if the user wants to cancel the operation or the user knows some buffers were lost and will never come.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStatistics.ResultAutoAborted
member.summary: Count of failed buffers with operation result set to AUTO_ABORTED.

remarks.para: The data receiver may enter a state where packets arrive for a newer block while one or more packets for an older block are still missing.
The AutoResetOnLackOfResources parameter is the threshold of free buffers maintained by the data receiver.

If a packet arrives for a new block and only AutoResetOnLackOfResources buffers are currently available then all incomplete buffers that have not yet finished being filled are immediately returned with result code AUTO_ABORTED.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStatistics.ResultTooManyConsecutiveResends
member.summary: Count of failed buffers with operation result set to TOO_MANY_CONSECUTIVE_RESENDS.
member.remarks: The data receiver stops attempting to receive a block if a set of consecutive lost packets exceeds MaximumResendGroupSize.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStatistics.ResultInvalidDataFormat
member.summary: Count of failed buffers with operation result set to INVALID_DATA_FORMAT.
member.remarks: This happens when poorly formatted data was received from the GigE Vision transmitter.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStatistics.ResultResendsFailure
member.summary: Count of failed buffers with operation result set to RESENDS_FAILURE.

remarks.para: The data receiver has attempted to recover missing packets by issuing resend requests.
The maximum number of retries has been reached without having received the requested packet.
The MaximumResendRequestRetryByPacket property can be used to configure how many times the data receiver re-attempts a request for a lost packet.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvStatistics.ResultTooManyResends
member.summary: Count of failed buffers with operation result set to TOO_MANY_RESENDS.
member.remarks: The data receiver stops attempting to receive a block if too many packet resends were issued.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvSerialPortIPEngine
member.summary: Provides access to the serial port on an IP Engine (Pleora GigE Vision device).
member.remarks:
PvSerialPortIPEngine uses a proprietary serial communication protocol on top of the GigE Vision GVCP protocol. It does not support non-Pleora devices.
Use of the PvSerialPortIPEngine class to directly access the camera head will interfere with the synchronization between the IP Engine and the camera head. Avoid accessing IP Engine features linked to the camera head while using the PvSerialPortIPEngine class to interact with the camera head.
How to use this class
To use a serial port:
Connect to a device using any of the Connect method of PvDevice class.
Open a serial port to the device using Open method of PvSerialPortIPEngine class.
Write to the serial port using Write method of PvSerialPort class.
Read from the serial port using Read method of PvSerialPort class.
Finally close the serial port using Close method of PvSerialPortIPEngine class. To check if an IP Engine supports a specific serial port:
Connect to a device using any of the Connect method of PvDevice class.
Use the IsSupported static method of PvSerialPortIPEngine class. For a simple example illustrating how to use PvSerialPortIPEngine, refer to the sample entitled PvSerialPortIPEngineSample.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvFPSStabilizer.IsTimeToDisplay(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Checks whether displaying a frame now would bring us close to the desired display frame rate or not.
member.remarks: If the new frame will bring you closer to your desired frame rate, the method returns true and you send the frame to be displayed to a PvDisplayControl or your own display class. If it returns false, this new frame would bring you above the desired display rate. The frame can still be processed, etc. but displaying it would bring you above the desired frame rate. The expected course of action would then be to simply not display the frame and wait for a new incoming frame - instead of holding to the current one and trying to display it later.
member.param: The target (desired) display frame rate.
member.returns: True if the frame should be displayed, false if not.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvFPSStabilizer
member.summary: Display frame rate manager. Used to stabilize the frames-per-seconds displayed.
member.remarks: This class is pretty simple to use. Just instantiate an object and call the IsTimeToDisplay every time you have a new frame to display, specifying the desired frame rate. This class is not tied to the display. It simply keeps track of the times associated with displayed frames (IsTimeToDisplay returning true) in a circular buffer and uses this history to decide if it is time to display a new frame. This class is not part of the core of the eBUS SDK. It is provided as a utility class shared by some Pleora samples. You are welcomed to use it in your own applications if it can help.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBufferWriter.Converter
member.summary: Returns a reference to the internal buffer converter.

remarks.para: When writing the buffer to a file requires a conversion, it is performed automatically by the PvBufferWriter. The converter used for this operation can be configured using this method. As an example, a RGB filter could be set or the Bayer interpolation method could be selected.

Internally, the WhiteBalance method uses the following procedure:

item.description: Calculate the average colors in the image: Bavg, Gavg, Ravg.
Select the maximum of the three averages: Max = max (Bavg, Gavg, Ravg).
Set the new gains, where:
Bgain = Max / Bavg
Ggain = Max / Gavg
Rgain = Max / Ravg

x' = kx + y. Where:
x' is the modified color level (for one of red, blue, or green).
x is the original color level (for one of red, blue, or green).
k is the level multiplier.
y is the offset.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamBase.RetrieveBuffer(PvDotNet.PvBuffer@,PvDotNet.PvResult@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Attempt to retrieve a queued buffer.
member.param: A pointer to the buffer to be filled.
member.returns: The buffer has been properly queued The buffer could not be queued. See #PvResult::GetDescription for more information

remarks.para: /// The RetrieveBuffer method blocks until one of the following occurs: - The buffer is filled with a block (image or raw data). - The retrieve buffer operation times out: it exceeds aTimeout. - The acquisition fails (by being aborted, data receiver timeout as defined by ImageTimeout property, etc.)

Once the method returns, you can determine the ultimate success of the image acquisition by testing the aOperationResult parameter. For example, #RetrieveBuffer may return PvResult::Code::OK, even if the operation was aborted (by a call to #AbortQueuedBuffers or #Close). In this case, aOperationResult would be PvResult::Code::ABORTED.

The return value contains the RetrieveBuffer operation results and aOperationResult contains the actual result (or failure) of the data receiver on this buffer. This method can succeed in providing you the oldest buffer but the result of the operation may still be a failure - if acquisition was aborted, incomplete, etc.

Once the method returns, you can determine the ultimate success of the image acquisition by testing the aOperationResult parameter. For example, #RetrieveBuffer may return PvResult::Code::OK, even if the operation was aborted (by a call to #AbortQueuedBuffers or #Close). In this case, aOperationResult would be PvResult::Code::ABORTED.

member.param: The buffer that holds the image.
Result of the acquisition operation on aBuffer, see
member.returns: The buffer is filled properly The system is unable to retrieve a buffer and timeouts. The stream is not connected to a transmitter. No buffers queued.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamBase.QueueBuffer(PvDotNet.PvBuffer)
member.summary: Queue a buffer to receive a block.
member.param: A pointer to the buffer to be filled.
member.returns: The buffer has been properly queued The buffer could not be queued. See #PvResult::GetDescription for more information

remarks.para: The QueueBuffer method queues in a buffer (PvBuffer object) to a stream (PvStream object) so it can be filled by the data receiver.

For each buffer you remove (using RetrieveBuffer), you should queue another (using QueueBuffer). The maximum number of buffers that can be queued at a given time can be obtained by calling GetQueuedBufferMaximum. To reduce the risk of missing incoming data, it is recommended that several blocks remain queued and ready to go at any given time. Generally it is recommended that a larger number of buffers remain queued for higher frame rates. Larger block sizes with blocks being streamed at a lower frame rate can afford to allocate fewer buffers to optimize memory usage and reduce potential latency.
Once the stream fills the buffer with a block, retrieve the buffer by calling RetrieveBuffer.

member.param: The buffer to be filled.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamBase.Open(System.String,System.String,System.UInt16,System.UInt16,System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Begin receiving blocks (images or raw data) multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter.

remarks.para: Note that this overload of Open is for receiving blocks that are multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter to a given multicast group. To receive unicasted data, refer to the other group of overloads of the Open method.
Multicasting is the delivery of data to a group of receivers simultaneously in a single transmission.

The following example illustrates how to multicast data from one transmitter to a given set of receivers:
Connect receivers and transmitter to an IGMP compliant switch.
The GigE Vision transmitter begins transmitting to a multicast group (i.e. 239.192.1.1:1042).
The GigE Vision transmitter has a control channel listening for device discovery requests and packet resend requests on a given IP address (i.e. 169.254.1.1).
Receiver applications discover the device and subscribe to the multicast group (call Open( "169.254.1.1", "239.192.1.1", 1042 ))

Why does the GigE Vision device address (aIPAddress) need to be specified? In this example, the data is transmitted using the GVSP protocol to a multicast group (239.192.1.1:1042). The receiving application contacts the device (IP address 169.254.1.1) using the GVCP protocol to ensure that it is reachable. In addition to this, packet resend requests are directed from receiver to GigE Vision device using the GVCP control channel. This is by design as per the GigEVision standard.

Multicasting uses the IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol) and requires an IGMP-compliant switch. The switch maintains a list of subscribed peers associated with a given multicast group. Multicast group IP addresses take the form 239.192.xx.yy. It is also possible to use multicasting with a non-IGMP compliant switch or network. In that case, the multicast stream is simply broadcasted to every connected entity on the network. It can be OK in controlled environment, but use with caution! To learn more about IGMPv3, see RFC 3376 at www.ietf.org.

For a complete illustration of how to use this method to receive data multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter, refer to the following two samples:
PvMulticastMasterSample - Connects to a GigE Vision device as a controler and tells it to begin streaming to a multicast address.
PvMulticastSlaveSample - Illustrates the use of multicast version of Open by receiving the data the GigE Vision device is transmitting.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvStreamBase.Open(System.String,System.String,System.UInt16,System.UInt16,System.String)
member.summary: Begin receiving blocks (images or raw data) multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter.
member.remarks:
Note that this overload of Open is for receiving blocks that are multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter to a given multicast group. To receive unicasted data, refer to the other group of overloads of the Open method.
Multicasting is the delivery of data to a group of receivers simultaneously in a single transmission.
The following example illustrates how to multicast data from one transmitter to a given set of receivers:
Connect receivers and transmitter to an IGMP compliant switch.
The GigE Vision transmitter begins transmitting to a multicast group (i.e. 239.192.1.1:1042).
The GigE Vision transmitter has a control channel listening for device discovery requests and packet resend requests on a given IP address (i.e. 169.254.1.1).
Receiver applications discover the device and subscribe to the multicast group (call Open( "169.254.1.1", "239.192.1.1", 1042 ))
Why does the GigE Vision device address (aIPAddress) need to be specified? In this example, the data is transmitted using the GVSP protocol to a multicast group (239.192.1.1:1042). The receiving application contacts the device (IP address 169.254.1.1) using the GVCP protocol to ensure that it is reachable. In addition to this, packet resend requests are directed from receiver to GigE Vision device using the GVCP control channel. This is by design as per the GigEVision standard.
Multicasting uses the IGMP (Internet Group Management Protocol) and requires an IGMP-compliant switch. The switch maintains a list of subscribed peers associated with a given multicast group. Multicast group IP addresses take the form 239.192.xx.yy. It is also possible to use multicasting with a non-IGMP compliant switch or network. In that case, the multicast stream is simply broadcasted to every connected entity on the network. It can be OK in controlled environment, but use with caution! To learn more about IGMPv3, see RFC 3376 at www.ietf.org.
For a complete illustration of how to use this method to receive data multicasted from a GigE Vision transmitter, refer to the following two samples:
PvMulticastMasterSample - Connects to a GigE Vision device as a controler and tells it to begin streaming to a multicast address.
PvMulticastSlaveSample - Illustrates the use of multicast version of Open by receiving the data the GigE Vision device is transmitting.
member.param: The GigE Vision transmitter's IP address.

The multicast IP address to which the receiver subscribes and the GigE Vision transmitter sends data. (Set the streaming channel destination address (SCDA) on your GigE Vision transmitter accordingly by calling PvDevice.StreamDestination.)

The multicast port to which the receiver subscribes and the GigE Vision transmitter sends data. (Set the streaming channel port (SCP) on your GigE Vision transmitter accordingly by calling PvDevice.StreamDestination.)
The GigE Vision transmitter's streaming channel (default 0).

The local IP address upon which to begin receiving incoming data. An empty string (default) indicates that the local IP address will be assigned automatically. Call #GetLocalIPAddress afterwards to obtain the local IP address that was assigned by the system. Set the streaming channel port number (SCP) on your GigE Vision transmitter accordingly by calling PvDevice.StreamDestination.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenStateStack
member.summary: Performs changes to a GenICam node map, tracks them and restores the previous state on destruction.

remarks.para: This class can be used to make temporary changes to a GenICam node map. Every parameter changed through this class is tracked and its original value is saved. When the object is destroyed, the original value of all parameters is restored in the reverse order.

This class is very useful when dealing with selectors. If you want to change a selected value without affecting the current selector state of the node map, create an object of this type, change the selector(s) using the Set methods, perform your changes and let the object go out of scope: the selectors will go back to their original values.

Assume A is originally 1, B is 2, C is 3. If you use this class to change A 4, B to 5 and C to 6 (in that order) when the object goes out of scope C will be set back to 3, B to 2 and A to 1 (in that order as well).
If a value cannot be set (an error occurs) the previous value is not pushed on the stack of parameters that will be restored when the destructor is called.

If the parameter is already set to the requested value, its value IS NOT changed, and IS NOT pushed on the stack to be eventually restored. This is done to minimize traffic to the device and to avoid having too many invalidators to be fired when a selector is already set to the right value.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvSystem.FindDevice(System.String)
member.summary: Finds devices until a specific device is found.

remarks.para: Performs a standard find operation and keeps listening for answers until a specific device is found.
More than one device can be found and added to the interfaces during this find operation. Do not assume only the device of interest is present in the system/interface data after this method returns.
If the device of interest is found, a reference to the device info in the interface where the device was found is returned.

member.param: String representing the device to find. Can be a MAC, IP or device name.
member.returns: A handle to a object, or NULL if the requested device is not found.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterRaw.MaxPayloadThroughput
member.summary: Gets and sets the maximum desired effective throughput in bps.

remarks.para: An occasional delay is placed between the packets being transmitted to attempt to throttle the effective throughput. This helps to spread out network traffic to optimize bandwidth availability for other applications.
A value of 0 (default) indicates that there should be no throttling based on throughput.

The throughput is measured in effective throughput on the content of the transmitted PvBuffer objects. It does not take into account the GigE Vision, UDP, IP and Ethernet protocol overhead of the packetized data.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterRaw.PacketSize
member.summary: Gets and sets the maximum packet size (in bytes) of GVSP payload packets.

remarks.para: When a block is packetized and transmitted, the payload is broken down into packets of a given size. The default value for the maximum packet size is 1440 because that is the size that should work in theory for all network adapters.

For best results, enable jumbo packets in your network adapter properties and increase the maximum packet size to match When sending very small blocks at high frame rates it may sometimes be desirable to set the maximum packet size to a lower number.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvTransmitterRaw
member.summary: Class for transmitting blocks using the GigE Vision streaming protocol.
member.remarks:
Procedure for transmitting blocks (images or raw data) with the eBUS SDK:
Ensure that the transmitter knows where to send blocks by calling Open.
Initialize the transmitter with a set of free buffers (PvBuffer objects) by calling LoadBufferPool.
Retrieve a free buffer to populate by calling RetrieveFreeBuffer.
Queue a buffer for transmission by calling QueueBuffer.
Once a buffer has been transmitted, it can be retrieved again by calling RetrieveFreeBuffer. The following code snippet illustrates procedure above: The status of a given PvBuffer object can be retrieved by calling OperationResult property of PvBuffer.
An operation result of indicates that the buffer was transmitted successfully.
An operation result of indicates that there was a problem transmitting the buffer (likely due to a lack of connectivity).
An operation result of indicates that the transmission of that buffer was aborted (typically by calling AbortQueuedBuffers).
An operation result of indicates that the buffer has not yet been fully transmitted. To receive transmitted blocks with a PvStream application (such as GEVPlayer), the transmitting application must be set up to respond to device discovery requests. Use PvVirtualDevice to respond to device discovery requests. If using GEVPlayer or NetCommand to receive data being transmitted with this class, ensure that the application is set up as Data Receiver Only. For an illustration of how this API is used in practice, refer to the following source code samples in the samples directory where the eBUS SDK resides.
PvTransmitTestPatternSample - Transmits a test pattern to a given destination. Easiest starting point for learning to use PvTransmitterRaw.
PvTransmitRawSample - Transmits raw data to a given destination. To be used in conjunction with PvReceiveRawSample.
PvReceiveRawSample - Receives raw data from a given source.
PvTransmitVideoSample - Captures from either a video file or an installed capture device (such as a webcam) using OpenCV and transmits it to a given destination.
PvTransformAndTransmitSample - Receives video from a GigE Vision device using PvStream and PvPipeline, resample it and print text on it using OpenCV and finally transmits it using PvTransmitterRaw.
PvTransmitScreenSample - Captures the contents of the screen and transmits it to a given destination.
PvTransmitTiledImageSample - An MFC GUI application that receives video from multiple GEV transmitters, tiles into one video feed and transmits to a given destination.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvSerialBridge.HardCodedBaudRate
member.summary: Returns the IP Engine hard-coded baud rate (user-defined).

remarks.para: Zero (0) is returned if the bridge is not started or in serial COM port mode.
Sets the IP Engine hard-coded baud rate (user-defined)

If the IP Engine GenICam interface does not have the features to control the configuration of the serial port used by the bridge, the developer must know and provide the baud rate to which the serial port is hard-coded.

This hard-coded baud rate is only used to control which unique baud rate is made available to the application or CLProtocol DLL using the Camera Link DLL. This unique baud rate must match the hard-coded IP Engine serial port baud rate.
This method should be called after starting the Camera Link DLL bridge, but before starting the application using the Camera Link DLL or before creating the CLProtocol node map.

With a serial COM port, the baud rate of the COM port is specified through the PvSerialPortConfiguration parameter passed to the Start method and simply isn't used to set the IP Engine serial port baud rate. The hard coded baud rate does not need to be defined.

If the IP Engine GenICam interface does not have the features to control the configuration of the serial port and this method is not called to specify the hard-coded baud rate of the serial port, 9600 baud is used/assumed.

Valid baud rates are the intersection between the IP Engine serial port baud rates and what is described in the Camera Link specification:
9600 baud.
19200 baud.
38400 baud.
57600 baud.
115200 baud.

member.exception:
Failure to set the IP Engine hard-coded baud rate can produce a PvException of the following result codes:
if the bridge is not started.
if the baud rate is not supported.
if the bridge is not in Camera Link DLL mode.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvSerialBridge
member.summary: Bridges a COM port of Camera Link DLL to an IP Engine serial port.

remarks.para: Notes: This class is only available on Windows.
The serial bridge takes all the data coming from either a COM port or eBUS SDK Camera Link DLL (clserpte.dll) and sends to an IP Engine serial port.
It also takes all the data coming from an IP Engine serial port and sends it to either a COM port or eBUS SDK Camera Link DLL.
Depending on the Start method that is used, the bridge is either started as a COM port bridge or Camera Link DLL bridge.
Statistics can be retrieved about a bridge: count of transmitted and received bytes.

The COM port can be used with a stand-alone application, usually a camera configuration application relying on a COM port (ie: COM1, COM2, etc.) to interact with the camera. The port selected by the application must be connected with a NULL modem to the port used by the bridge. It can be two real COM ports connected together or two virtual ports with a COM port emulation software/driver.

The Camera Link DLL can be used with a stand-alone application, usually a camera configuration application, relying on the API described in the Camera Link standard used to interface a serial port. Instead of being the serial port of a frame grabber here it is the serial port of a GigE Vision IP Engine.
The Camera Link DLL can also be used with a PvGenParameterArrayCL - a GenICam CLProtocol interface.
For a simple example illustrating how to use PvSerialBridge, refer to the sample entitled PvSerialBridgeSample.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkWrite
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port write.

remarks.para: Used to report write activity on the GenApi iPort implementation of the GVCP command link of the PvDevice.
The callback is invoked AFTER the write operation. The content of aBuffer represents the data that was written to the device.
This callback is only invoked on a successful read operation.

If the delegate aLength parameter is 4 bytes, that data is represented as a 4 byte value formatted as big-endian. If data is more that 4 bytes, it is presented as a stream of bytes requiring proper interpretation.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnCmdLinkRead
member.summary: Callback invoked after a port read.

remarks.para: Used to report read activity on the GenApi iPort implementation of the GVCP command link of the PvDevice.
The callback is invoked AFTER the read operation so the content of aBuffer contains the data that was read from the device.
This callback is only invoked on a successful read operation.

If the delegate aLength parameter is 4 bytes, that data is represented as a 4 byte value formatted as big-endian. If data is more that 4 bytes, it is presented as a stream of bytes requiring proper interpretation.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnEventGenICam
member.summary: Messaging channel GenICam event notification.

remarks.para: This OnEvent handler lets users access the GigE Vision event as mapped through the GigE Vision interface of the device.

Unlike the other OnEvent that provides a pointer to the raw event data, the data is provided as a list of GenICam parameters that have been invalidated when the event has been attached to the GenApi node map of the device.

If events with no data or events with data not mapped in the GenICam interface of the device are received, this callback is still invoked by the parameter list containing is not provided, it is simply set to NULL.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: E:PvDotNet.PvDevice.OnEvent
member.summary: Messaging channel raw event notification.

remarks.para: If the delegate aData parameter is not NULL, it is as received on the wire in the device's endianess. All other parameters are corrected for the host's endianess.
The OnEvent handler lets users access the raw GigE Vision event before it is forwarded to the GenICam layer.
It is highly recommended to always use the OnEventGenICam when possible. Use of raw events assume a good knowledge of the device implementation like event ID and data mapping.
See delegate documentation for more information.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.RecoveryThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the recovery thread
member.remarks:
This thread is used to fire/invoke the OnLinkDisconnected and OnLinkReconnected PvDeviceEventSink events.
If you change the thread priorities, it may alterate the stability of the system. For this reason, if you report a bug to Pleora, ensure to clearly mention that you change threads priorities.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.InterruptQueueThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the interrupt queue thread
member.remarks:
This thread is simply used to fire/invoke the OnLinkDisconnected and OnLinkReconnected PvDeviceEventSink events.
This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.InterruptLinkThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the interrupt link thread
member.remarks:
Interrupt link thread receives messaging channel packets from the device, sends acknowledge back and queues the message in the interrupt queue. Process and callbacks are not done from this thread.
This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvDevice.HeartbeatThreadPriority
member.summary: Set / Get the priority of the heartbeat thread

remarks.para: The heartbeat thread priority is critical to most applications. This thread must never starve against any other system thread to the risk of losing the device connection.

This thread takes all messages queued for deferred processing by the interrupt link thread and fires all GenApi and PvDeviceEventSink callback. All callbacks are fired/run in the context of this thread.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvDevice.WriteRegister(System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Write a 32-bit value to a specific register address on the GigE Vision device.
member.remarks:
This is an advanced method and is rarely needed. In general, most users should instead use the device's GenICam interface which can be obtained through GetGenParameters.
The WriteRegister and ReadRegister methods let advanced users control third-party GigE Vision devices with poor or incomplete GenICam XML files. The methods presume detailed working knowledge of the GigE Vision device's register map. Since the WriteRegister method bypasses the GenICam interface and the SDK's cache of values, incorrect use may cause indeterminate results.
aValue as used with ReadRegister and WriteRegister are provided in the platform's expected endianness. GigE Vision single register operations are always performed as big-endian and on Intel platforms are corrected to/from little-endian.
member.param: The GigE Vision device's register address (mod 4).
The value to be written to the register.

When sending the command, sets the acknowledge requested bit and waits for that acknowledge. If set to false, the acknowledge is not requested and the method returns as soon as the command has been pushed in the UDP socket.
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
TIMEOUT

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvDevice
member.summary: Connect, configure and control a GigE Vision device.
member.remarks:
To connect and configure a GigE Vision device to begin transmitting data:
Select the GigE Vision device to which you want to connect. See PvSystem, PvInterface, PvDeviceInfo.
Connect to a GigE Vision device. Use Connect.
Get the GigE Vision device's GenICam interface. Use GetGenParameters.
Configure the device through the GenICam interface. See PvGenParameterArray.
Configure the receiver and take note of its IP address and port.
Configure your PvDevice's streaming destination using SetStreamDestination.
Lock the interface for streaming. Set TLParamsLocked feature of the GigE Vision device's GenICam interface to 1.
Configure the GigE Vision device to send images. Use AcquisitionStart feature of the GigE Vision device's GenICam interface.
Release the interface for streaming. Set TLParamsLocked feature of the GigE Vision device's GenICam interface to 0.
Configure the GigE Vision device to stop sending images. Use AcquisitionStop feature of the GigE Vision device's GenICam interface.
For a complete example that illustrates the steps above, refer to the following samples:
PvMulticastMasterSample - Configure a GigE Vision device to transmit.
PvPipelineSample - Configure a GigE Vision device to transmit and receive the data it transmits in the same application.Recovery
The SDK can let you automatically recover from problems such as accidental disconnects, power interrupts, and so on. To learn more, see PvDeviceEventSink.

Event ID. Some standard GigE Vision event IDs are defined but usually device dependent.
Streaming channel associated with the event, if any. 0xFFFF is used if the event is not associated to a streaming channel.
Streaming block ID associated with the event, if any. Can be used to pair one or more than one event with a block received from a device. 0 is used if the event is not associated to a block.
Timestamp of the event on the time domain of the device. Time unit is defined by the device. 0 if timestamps are not supported by the device that generated the event.
List containing all parameters invalidated by this event. Can be null if the event carried no data or the data was does not not invalidate any GenICam parameters of the device.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvGenParameterArray.AttachDataChunks(PvDotNet.PvBuffer)
member.summary: Attaches a payload containing data chunks to a GenICam node map.

remarks.para: Takes the content of a PvBuffer and attempts to parse the chunks from the end of the buffer. Chunk IDs from the buffer matching chunk IDs in the node map are available through the node map once the buffer is attached.
Using GenICam instead of the PvBuffer raw chunk methods access allows to access the chunks as structured data, as long as the chunks are described in the GenICam XML file of the device.

member.param: Pointer to the a PvBuffer containing data chunks

The buffer is not attached or allocated or has invalid size.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenParameterArray
member.summary: GenICam feature array.

remarks.para: 1- Get the list of features. Use one of the following:

item.description: PvDevice.GenParameters (Parameters used to control the GigE Vision device to which you are connected).
PvDevice.GenLink (Parameters used to define how PvDevice connects to and communicates with the device - see Device Communication Parameters).
PvStream.Parameters (Parameters used to define how PvStream receives data from a GigE Vision transmitter - see Stream Parameters).

remarks.para: 2- Get a feature. Use .
3- Get the feature's type. Use .

4- Optionally:
Get/Set the feature's value. Use the Value attribute for the feature's type (e.g. PvGenInteger.Value, etc).
If the feature is a command, activate it. Use PvGenCommand.Execute.
To control features (using a GUI): see PvGenBrowserWnd

para.h3: Running code when a feature's value changes

remarks.para: In some cases, you may want to know when a feature value or attribute changes without using CPU-intensive polling to regularly check (and re-check) the feature's value.
To create a callback that runs when the feature's value changes:

item.description: Get the feature. See Controlling features.
Create a subclass of .
Use the PvGenParameter events and delegates to be notified when a parameter is invalidated.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.GetPayloadSize
member.summary: Returns payload size in bytes, excluding any extra padding.

remarks.para: Gets the size in bytes of the block received by the data receiver including, if present, additional chunk data and headers.
Different than GetAcquiredSize as it does not include optional additional padding when data chunks are present.
If data chunks are not present, this method returns the same value as GetAcquiredSize as extra padding is only an issue when data chunks are present.
This method is required in order to parse the chunk data using GenICam.

member.returns: Payload size in bytes, excluding any extra padding.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.ChunkCount
member.summary: Returns the number of data chunks in the PvBuffer.

remarks.para: If no data chunks are available, 0 is returned.
Counting chunks requires the chunks to be parsed and resolved which has a performance hit.

If you need to access chunks directly, you need to use this method to enumerate the chunks. If you access the chunks through GenICam, just use HasChunks to see if you need to attach the buffer the GenICam parameter array of the device.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.HasChunks
member.summary: \Returns true if the buffer has data chunks.

remarks.para: Unlike GetChunkCount, chunks do not need to be parsed or resolved with this method.

member.summary: Gets the interface to the buffer or NULL, depending on payload type.

remarks.para: If the payload type of the PvBuffer is PvPayloadTypeRawData, a reference to a interface of the buffer is returned.
If the payload type of the PvBuffer is NOT PvPayloadTypeRawData, a null reference is returned.
This handle is owned by the PvBuffer and does not need to be released after use. It is valid as long as the PvBuffer exists.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.GetMissingPacketIds(System.UInt32,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Gets a missing packet group that represents an unpopulated area of memory in this buffer.

remarks.para: This is an advanced feature that requires knowledge of how GigE Vision data is transmitted. Refer to for further details on how this feature is used.

member.param: The index of the missing packet group being retrieved.
The first packet of a range of missing packets.

The last packet of a range of missing packets. A value of 0xFFFFFF ( or 0xFFFFFFFF for ExtendedID ) indicates that the last packet of the block went missing and therefore the actual size of the block is unknown.
member.exception:
Failure can produce a containing one of the following result codes:
NOT_AVAILABLE.
NOT_IMPLEMENTED./>

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.MissingPacketIdsCount
member.summary: Gets the number of missing packet groups that represent unpopulated areas of memory in this buffer.

remarks.para: This is an advanced feature that requires knowledge of how GigE Vision data is transmitted.

When receiving data from a GigE Vision transmitter, network conditions may prevent the successful delivery of all the data for a given block. Although the eBUS data receiver provides a mechanism for requesting lost packets, there are cases when it is desirable to ignore missing packets and make use of a buffer that contains missing information. In some cases, there are portions of a block that are less important and can thus be disregarded. GetMissingPacketIdsCount and GetMissingPacketIds can provide information about which packets were lost. To use this feature take note of the following procedure:

item.description: Enable the feature that causes the data receiver to keep track of missing packets (see the EnableMissingPacketsList property of PvStream).
Optionally disable the mechanism that requests lost packets (see the RequestMissingPackets property of PvStream).
Check the operation result when a new block is received (see ).
If the operation result is MISSING_PACKETS, use property MissingPacketIdsCount to determine how many groups of packets are missing.
Iterate through the missing packet groups using .
Note that there is no particular order to the missing packet groups that are returned.
Take note of the packet size set on the GigE Vision transmitter from which you are receiving to determine the areas of the payload where information is missing.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.IsTrailerValid
member.summary: True if this buffer has valid trailer (GVSP) information.

remarks.para: If the buffer trailer is not valid (missing) some information about the buffer could be missing. As an example, the image payload type confirms the number of lines received in the trailer.
When a buffer is attached or allocated for use other than receiving GVSP data, this attribute evaluates to true in order to appear as valid.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.IsHeaderValid
member.summary: True if this buffer has valid header (GVSP) information.

remarks.para: If the buffer header is not valid (missing) the buffer has to be manipulated with extreme caution. To start with, it is impossible to confirm the payload type. The timestamp and other shared header information is not valid. Finally, information specific to some payload types (like with, height, pixel format, etc. for the image payload type) is not available or valid this buffer.
When a buffer is attached or allocated for use other than receiving GVSP data, this attribute evaluates to true in order to appear as valid.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.IsExtendedID
member.summary: Check if the buffer is currently in extended ID mode.

remarks.para: When the extended ID mode is not enabled, the maximum block ID is 0xFFFFFF and the maximum packet ID is 0xFFFFFF as per the GEV 1.X specification. When the extended ID mode is enabled, the maximum block ID is 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF and the maximum packet ID is 0xFFFFFFFF as per the GEV 2.X specification.

When a PvBuffer is received, the extended ID mode is initialized based on the information received by the PvStreamLib.Stream. When a PvBuffer is sent, the extended ID mode will be initialized by the PvTransmitterRaw.PvTransmitterRaw according to its configuration.
Returns true if the extended mode is in usage.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.OperationResult
member.summary: Gets the value of aOperationResult when this buffer was last received through a PvStream. See also PvStreamBase::RetrieveBuffer, PvPipeline::RetrieveNextBuffer.

remarks.para: Buffers with BUFFER_TOO_SMALL, ABORTED, NOT_CONNECTED and NO_MORE_ITEM operation results are never returned to the user with PvPipeline. PvPipeline handles these operation results internally without returning the buffers. Buffers with these operation results can only reach the user when using PvStream directly.
Result of the acquisition operation; Includes: for images with grabber issues like data overrun or missing lines (complete or partial)

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.Timestamp
member.summary: Gets the buffer's timestamp.
member.remarks: For Pleora GigE Vision devices, this is the value of the GevTimestampValue when it began receiving data from the camera head (on the rising edge of the FVAL).

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvBuffer.BlockID
member.summary: Gets the block ID.
member.remarks: This method returns the block ID. The GigE Vision transmitter typically increments the value by 1 for each new image. You can use this value to ensure the blocks are in order and that none are missing. The value is unsigned and wraps around to 1 (skipping 0) when it reaches 65536.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvBuffer
member.summary: Represents a block of GigE Vision data in memory.

remarks.para: A PvBuffer object is typically used to receive data from a GigE Vision transmitter or to transmit data to a GigE Vision receiver. To learn about receiving data from a GigE Vision transmitter, see PvStream. To learn about transmitting GigE Vision data to a GigE Vision receiver, see PvTransmitterRaw.
A block of GigE Vision data has an associated payload which can be an image, raw data, file, chunk data, extended chunk data or device specific.
In order to access the payload specific data, use property in order to get a handle to an interface giving you access to payload specific methods and properties.
The current payload type of a PvBuffer can be determined by using the method.
In this section:

item.description: Creating and configuring buffers.
Accessing payload type specific data.
Processing images.

para.b: To determine the payload type and access payload type specific data:

item.description: Retrieve the PvPayloadType using .
If PvPayloadType is PvPayloadTypeImage, retrieve reference from your PvBuffer.
Access image specific data through the reference, like , , etc.
There is no need to release or delete the reference. It is valid as long as the PvBuffer exists.
Retrieve a interface to the buffer use property..
Test the success of the image acquisition. Use the aOperationResult parameter in PvStream::RetrieveBuffer or PvBuffer::GetOperationResult.
Process the image using your own code. You may process the image in place, if you wish. Use:
PvImage.AcquiredSize.
PvImage.Height and PvImage.Width.
PvImage.OffsetX and PvImage.OffsetY.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvImage.CopyFromBitmap(System.Drawing.Bitmap,PvDotNet.PvPixelType)
member.summary: Copies the content of a .NET Bitmap to the PvImage.
member.remarks: Prior to the copy, the PvImage is resized to hold the complete bitmap. The PvPixelType is used as destination. Color BGRA8Packed, BGR8Packed, RGBA8Packed, RGB8Packed, WinRGB24, WinBGR24, WinRGB32 and WinBGR32 PvPixelType are currently supported. The input has to be either Format32bppRgb, Format32bppArgb or Format24bppRgb.
member.param: The bitmap from which to copy the data.
The pixel type to convert to when copying the data to the PvImage.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvImage.PaddingY
member.summary: Gets the vertical image padding, in bytes.

remarks.para: Additional bytes appended at the end of an image. See

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvImage.PaddingX
member.summary: Gets the horizontal image padding, in bytes; the number of bytes at the end of an image's line that contain meaningless data.

remarks.para: Images lines could be grabbed in increments of, let's say, 32 bytes. For an image 511 bytes across, the IP Engine adds a meaningless byte to make the line total 512 bytes (divisible by 32). In this case, the paddingX value would be 1 (byte).
Other GigE Vision devices may have different requirements on line length. Drivable by 4, 8, 16, etc. or no specific limitations or requirements.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvImage.EffectiveImageSize
member.summary: Gets the effective image size. Uses same size x and y as but excludes all padding.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvImage.ImageSize
member.summary: Gets actual image size within the payload or buffer.

remarks.para: Uses the GEV leader for the actual width.
Uses the GEV trailer for line count which is the actual height.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvImage.RequiredSize
member.summary: Gets the size of buffer required to hold the acquired image.

remarks.para: This attribute is valid if the last image acquisition was successful or if it failed because the buffer was too small. It can be used to re-allocate the acquisition buffers if the acquisition failed because the buffer was too small.
The required size is only computed for the last image - based on the number of lines as provided in the GigE Vision streaming protocol trailer.
It is possible that with devices outputting images of varying length (like line scan cameras) that the last image required size may be smaller than the maximum possible size.
In order to be 100% sure of allocating buffers correctly, you should either hard code the buffer size to known big enough sizes or use the device GenICam GevPayloadSize parameter for dynamic cases.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvImage
member.summary: Image interface to a PvBuffer.

remarks.para: A PvBuffer represents a generic buffer with no specific payload type. If the payload type is image, the user can obtain a reference to a PvImage buffer interface through the PvBuffer.Image attribute.
This PvImage reference is owned by the PvBuffer and does not need to be released after use. It is valid as long as the PvBuffer exists.

para.b: To determinate the payload type and access image specific data:

item.description: Retrieve the PvPayloadType using the PvBuffer.PayloadType attribute
If PvPayloadType is PvPayloadTypeImage, retrieve a PvImage reference from your PvBuffer
Access image specific data through a PvImage reference, like , , etc.
There is no need to release or delete the PvImage reference. It is valid as long as the PvBuffer exists.

member.name: M:PvDotNet.PvGenRegister.Set(System.Byte*,System.Int64)

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvGenEnum
member.summary: GenICam feature: Enumeration. A feature that can take one of many defined values.

remarks.para: In group: GenICam features.
PvGenEnum is a list of selectable values. In a UI, PvGenEnum objects are typically represented as dropdown lists.
Each list entry is a object.
Thus, the enumeration list might be represented as:
However, the UI presents only a selection of entry names (Orange, etc.); the list position and entry values are hidden. The entry names are always unique.
Enumerations can't be set to any arbitrary value; they can only be set to a value of an entry on the list.
If a user selected Orange, you could set the new value in the following ways:

item.description: Set the entry value directly with = 5.
Set the entry value by the name with = "Orange".

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvException
member.summary: Exception class wrapping a PvResult object. Used for most of the error management in the eBUS SDK.

remarks.para: Every feature has a visibility setting that suggests how difficult the feature is to use and when it shouldn't be made available (visible) to the end user.
The current visibility might be a program-specific variable available, for example, in an options or configuration dialog.
When opening the program for the first time, the visibility would typically be set to beginner.
If a program's current visibility were set to Expert, the user would expect to see Beginner and Expert-level features, but not Guru or Invisible-level features.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvResult.OSCode
member.summary: Retrieves the internal OS code that may have triggered the error.

remarks.para: The user is not expected to be able to interpret this error code, it can widely vary based on the platform or even API that generated it. It can be used in order to provide more information to Pleora support personnel.

member.name: P:PvDotNet.PvResult.InternalCode
member.summary: Returns the internal error code of the error.

remarks.para: This method can be used to retrieve the internal error code that was mapped to the public error code contained in the PvResult.
The user is not expected to be able to interpret this error code. It can be used in order to provide more information to Pleora support personnel.

member.name: T:PvDotNet.PvResult
member.summary: Result information.

remarks.para: The PvResult class provides information about the success or failure of the methods you use.
Most successful methods return , however, there are exceptions:

item.description: Some methods return immediately, but the ultimate success of the method may not be know for some time after (several seconds or more). These methods return . Pending operations are considered successful.

para.b: To use result codes (best coding practices):

item.description: Call a method.
Test the result for success. Use , , or test against specific PvResult::Code values.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NO_MORE_ITEM
member.summary: No more of what was requested is currently available.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.THREAD_ERROR
member.summary: An error occurred while attempting to perform an operation on a thread like starting, stopping or changing priority.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NO_AVAILABLE_DATA
member.summary: There is no available data to enumerate.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NETWORK_ERROR
member.summary: A network error occurred while performing the requested operation.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NO_MORE_ENTRY
member.summary: There are no more entries to retrieve/enumerate.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.BAD_VERSION
member.summary: Some component versions are not compatible.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.AUTO_ABORTED
member.summary: Buffer reception failed. The data receiver entered a state where so many packets and/or blocks were missing that all queued buffers were automatically aborted on an internal reset.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.TOO_MANY_CONSECUTIVE_RESENDS
member.summary: Buffer reception failed, consecutive missing buffers higher than allowed. The data receiver may stop attempting to receive a block if a set of consecutive packets exceeding MaximumResendGroupSize.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.RESENDS_FAILURE
member.summary: Failure to receive all missing packets for a buffer through resend packets.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.TOO_MANY_RESENDS
member.summary: Too many resend packets were requested, buffer acquisition failure.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.BUFFER_TOO_SMALL
member.summary: The buffer was not large enough to hold the payload of the block being received. Call PvBuffer::GetRequiredSize to use the information from the leader packet to determine the size of buffer that would have been required to receive the block. Call PvBuffer::Alloc or PvBuffer::Attach to allocate or associate an a larger area of memory to receive the next block.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.MISSING_PACKETS
member.summary: Some packets are missing in the buffer. Happens when at least one packet of the buffer is missing when it was released back to the calling application.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.IMAGE_ERROR
member.summary: Error with an image. May be returned when a corrupt image arrives due to discontinuities in data between the camera and the hardware responsible for transmitting packets in the GigE Vision device. This can include data overrun, partial and full lines missing.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.ERR_OVERFLOW
member.summary: Overflow occurred. Can happen when a counter overflows or when an attempt was made to write past the upper boundary of a file or data structure.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.FILE_ERROR
member.summary: A file operation error occurred.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The requested feature or functionality is not supported.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_IMPLEMENTED
member.summary: The requested feature or functionality is not implemented. Can happen when a dynamically selected feature or capability is not implemented in the SDK.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.GENICAM_XML_ERROR
member.summary: The GenICam XML file could not be loaded into GenApi. The file could be corrupted or simply incorrectly structured. Some third-party vendors use XML files that don't conform to the GenApi schema.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NO_LICENSE
member.summary: An eBUS SDK license is missing. To receive data from a GigE Vision device that does not contain a Pleora IP Engine, a receiver license is required. A license is also required to transmit data using the eBUS SDK using PvTransmitterRaw. When working with images, a watermark is applied when no license is present. This is so that the SDK can be used for evaluation purposes.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.TIMEOUT
member.summary: The operation timed out. The operation exceeded its specified maximum wait time without succeeding.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.PENDING
member.summary: Success. (Pending.) Returned by PvStreamRaw::QueueBuffer to indicate that a buffer has been successfully queued but the operation is still pending (the data has not yet been received).

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.CANCEL
member.summary: The user closed a dialog and the operation was not performed. This can occur if the "Cancel" button is clicked.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.INVALID_PARAMETER
member.summary: A parameter passed to the method is invalid.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.GENERIC_ERROR
member.summary: An undefined error occurred.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_ENOUGH_MEMORY
member.summary: An operation failed to complete as not enough memory was available.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.ABORTED
member.summary: The operation was aborted

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.INVALID_DATA_FORMAT
member.summary: The data format is not supported for the requested operation.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.STATE_ERROR
member.summary: The system's current state doesn't allow the action.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_CONNECTED
member.summary: The object isn't connected.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.CANNOT_OPEN_FILE
member.summary: The file doesn't exist or can't be opened.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_FOUND
member.summary: The expected item wasn't found.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.NOT_INITIALIZED
member.summary: An error code hasn't been set.

member.name: F:PvDotNet.PvResultCode.OK
member.summary: Success. For information about what constitutes success (and the exceptions), see PvResult.
